results.title: An Evening with Shaun Tan
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
To celebrate the exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From Book to Film’ a special evening with the Oscar®-winning animator, author and illustrator, Shaun Tan was held on 24 July 2013. He discussed the making of the exhibition, talked about his body of work and shared insights into his creative processes.
Shaun’s books, including ‘The Rabbits’, ‘The Red Tree’ and the acclaimed graphic novel ‘The Arrival’, have been widely translated and enjoyed by readers of all ages. His work as a feature film concept artist can be seen in films like ‘Wall-E’ (2008) and his Academy Award®-winning animated short ‘The Lost Thing’, which he also wrote and co-directed.
In 2011, Shaun received the prestigious Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award in Sweden. His attraction to children’s stories with confronting or puzzling ideas is reflected in his work, which encourages dialogue between adult readers and younger listeners.

results.title: An Evening with Charles Aznavour
results.creator_credit: Mike Mansfield, Patrick Shart, Phillip Goodhand and VCL Communications
results.brief_description: This is a video-taped program of the internationally acclaimed French singer/actor, Charles Aznavour, performing live at the Duke of York’s Theatre, London in 1982. The charming and entertaining Aznavour performs a selection of his popular songs accompanied by The Wren Orchestra, and vocal accompaniment from Sue Martin, Val Stokes and Lavinia Rogers. Musical direction by Peter Lee.

results.title: An Essay: the popular arts today
results.creator_credit: Saul Bass, Jim Ragan, Elaine Bass and Saul Bass Films
results.brief_description: A vignette on popular arts in America through the use of live-action, animation and special effects. Portrays Hollywood movies as a nightmare realm of casual predation and fatuous pomposity. Focuses also on comic book heros, television, music, books and magazines.

results.title: An Equal opportunity
results.creator_credit: Caroline Leaf, Robert Verrall, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People at Work”.
This open-ended drama is designed to trigger discussion on the subject of equal opportunities for women in the workplace and on the role of unions in securing those opportunities and working to eliminate discriminatory labour practices. Though set within a hospital and focussing on one of several staff women who are denied access to a pharmacy training program despite suitable qualifications, the underlying premises, conflicts and responses have implications that reach far beyond the hospital walls. Written by Gynne Basen, Clayton Bailey, Caroline Leaf; photographed by Wolf Koenig; edited by Judith Merritt; sound by John Martin, Bernie Bordeleau

results.title: A Right to refuse?
results.creator_credit: Clayton Bailey, Caroline Leaf, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “People at Work”.
Dramatization of an industrial conflict. Workers should realise that they have the right to refuse to do jobs under dangerous or unhealthy conditions.

results.title: An Enemy of the people = Ganashatru
results.creator_credit: Satyajit Ray and National Film Development Corporation of India
results.brief_description: Adaptation of Henrik Ibsen’s play of the same name, spoken in Bengali dialogue with English subtitles. In this version of Ibsen’s play, Satyajit Ray has transposed the action to contemporary India. When Dr. Ashok Gupta, chief medical officer at the hospital in the West Bengal town of Chandipur, discovers that the local ‘holy waters’ are dangerously polluted, his efforts to solve the problem are blocked by powerful local interests determined that nothing shall interfere with the lucrative flow of pilgrims and tourists. Gupta is, however, eventually supported by a coalition of progressive local interests, and the scene is set for a powerful conflict between science and superstition, idealism and self-interest. A fine example of ‘late’ Ray, and a fascinating fusion of Ray and Ibsen. Satyajit Ray was awarded an Honorary Oscar in 1992. Stars Soumitra Chatterjee, Dhritiman Chatterjee, Deepankar De, Ruma Cuhathakurta and Mamta Shankta.

results.title: An Elephant on his hands
results.brief_description:
Short silent comedy film starring Hughie Mack as Jonah Whale. Life takes a chaotic turn when Jonah inherits two elephants from his late uncle. Also stars Dot Farley.
With English intertitles.

results.title: An Easy pill to swallow
results.creator_credit: Robert Lang, Arthur Hammond, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Canadians are avid consumers of tranquillisers. This documentary, in the form of an ongoing dialogue for and against drugs, introduces us to doctors and patients who approach the issue from different angles. An “easy” pill could be a dangerous one, especially if we take it for granted. (Award: Columbus)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Lang, Arthur Hammond, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: An Awfully big adventure [J.R.R. Tolkien]
results.creator_credit: Julian Birkett, National Video Corporation and BBC
results.brief_description: This episode from a series on the making of modern children’s literature looks at the work of John Ronald Reuel, writer of the biggest selling children’s book ever, “The Hobbit” and creator of Middle Earth. The program discusses his childhood and education, his passion with language and phonology and his time at the Somme. It also talks about his literary influences (particularly Old Norse and Anglo Saxon literature), the formation of the Inklings with C.S. Lewis, his relationship with Allen and Unwin, and the evolution of the “Silmarillion.” Excerpts from “The Hobbit” are read and the plot of “The Lord of the rings” outlined. The program questions why Tolkien has universal appeal and looks at the acceptance of his work by counter culture America in the 1960s.
